docs.lead_paragraph: A three-year study of AIDS drugs has identified what the research leaders believe is the ideal triple-therapy cocktail for new patients. The successful cocktail, known colloquially as ''two nukes plus a non-nuke,'' is the same one that the World Health Organization has been recommending in poor countries since 2002. It is also the same combination that Indian suppliers of generic drugs have been putting in three-in-one pills since 2001.

headline.main: Made in India, a Favored 'Cocktail' for AIDS

docs.abstract: Study funded and monitored by National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which is part of National Institutes of Health, identifies ideal triple-therapy cocktail for new AIDS patients; known as two nukes plus a non-nuke, therapy is same one recommended by World Health Organization since 2002 and supplied by Indian pharmaceutical companies in generic form since 2001; study, published in New England Journal of Medicine and led by Dr Roy M Gulick of Weill Cornell Medical College, NYC, finds that after 32 weeks on cocktail, 98 percent of patients had almost undetectable amount of virus in blood; cocktail contains AZT, lamivudine and nevirapine (M)

keywords.value: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES

docs.lead_paragraph: For many elderly people, even a simple fall may result in a hip fracture and the serious health and mobility problems that can follow. A new study suggests that such fractures are much less likely to occur when the elderly live in homes where the floors are made of wood, not concrete, and are covered with carpet.

headline.main: How a Carpet Might Save a Hip

docs.abstract: Dr Sallie Lamb, University of Warwick, England, researcher, leads study that finds elderly are less likely to fall and break bones if walking on wood floor or carpeted wood floor; study, published in Age and Ageing, suggests changes to elderly residents' homes that would help prevent falls; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: For many elderly people, even a simple fall may result in a hip fracture and the serious health and mobility problems that can follow.    A new study suggests that such fractures are much less likely to occur when the elderly live in homes where the...

docs.lead_paragraph: On a recent Friday evening, nearly 200 people came to the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan to watch a master performance -- call it stand-up psychotherapy -- by a legend. As he has on nearly every Friday night for more than 30 years, Dr. Albert Ellis, the 90-year-old psychologist who invented rational emotive behavioral therapy and wrenched psychotherapy out of the age of Freud and into the age of Dr. Phil, was demonstrating his no-nonsense, confrontational, obscenity-laden technique before a packed house on East 65th Street.

headline.main: From Therapy's Lenny Bruce: Get Over It! Stop Whining!

docs.abstract: Ninety-year-old psychologist Albert Ellis participates in weekly Friday night demonstrations of his confrontational technique at Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan; is regarded as major icon of 20th century and ranked as second most influential psychotherapist by survey of clinical psychologists; center of therapy is Ellis's conviction that people can always choose to change and therapist's role is to nudge them in right direction; key elements of his practice and theory discussed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: On a recent Friday evening, nearly 200 people came to the Albert Ellis Institute in Manhattan to watch a master performance -- call it stand-up psychotherapy -- by a legend.    As he has on nearly every Friday night for more than 30 years, Dr. Albert...

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who have dental X-rays while pregnant may be at higher risk of having babies with low birth weights, researchers say. Writing in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers from the University of Washington in Seattle said that among women they studied, those with low-weight babies were twice as likely to have had multiple dental X-rays.
docs.abstract: Dr Philippe P Hujoel, University of Washington researcher, leads study that suggests women who undergo x-rays while pregnant may be at higher risk of low birth weight babies; study, published in Journal of the American Medical Assn, recommends that pregnant women refrain from elective x-rays; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Women who have dental X-rays while pregnant may be at higher risk of having babies with low birth weights, researchers say.    Writing in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers from the University of Washington in Seattle said...

keywords.value: JOURNAL OF THE AMERICAN MEDICAL ASSN

docs.lead_paragraph: For most people taking antidepressants, the risk of a diminished sex drive may seem like a worthwhile sacrifice for the benefits from the drugs. Up to 70 percent of patients on antidepressants report sexual side effects, yet the number of Americans who take the drugs has ballooned since Prozac was introduced in the late 1980's. Last year, studies show, doctors in the United States wrote 213 million prescriptions for antidepressants.

headline.main: Has the Romance Gone? Was It the Drug?

docs.abstract: Seventy percent of patients taking antidepressants report experiencing sexual side effects; prescriptions, however, for antidepressants continue to rise, with 213 million written in 2003; Rutgers University anthropologist Dr Helen E Fisher, speaking at annual meeting of American Psychiatric Assn, presents findings that suggest antidepressants can influence all aspects of relationships, including lust, attraction and attachment; holds that people taking antidepressants may have problems with romantic love (M)
docs.snippet: For most people taking antidepressants, the risk of a diminished sex drive may seem like a worthwhile sacrifice for the benefits from the drugs.     Up to 70 percent of patients on antidepressants report sexual side effects, yet the number of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Want to have a lower cholesterol level? Try having your blood tested in the warmer months. Cholesterol levels, researchers say in a new report, change with the seasons -- and are highest in the winter. The study appears in the current issue of Archives of Internal Medicine.
docs.abstract: Dr Ira S Ockene of University of Massachusetts Medical Center leads study that shows blood cholesterol levels change seasonally; findings, which are published in Archives of Internal Medicine, show highest readings in winter months; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Want to have a lower cholesterol level? Try having your blood tested in the warmer months.    Cholesterol levels, researchers say in a new report, change with the seasons -- and are highest in the winter. The study appears in the current issue of...

docs.lead_paragraph: Diabetes, a growing public health problem, can cause serious problems, including kidney failure and heart disease, often doing damage before any symptoms are felt. But if it is caught early, a lot of trouble can be prevented. So should screening for diabetes become a routine part of medical care? No, a new study published yesterday concludes.
docs.abstract: Dr Thomas J Hoerger, researcher at RTI International, leads study that suggests only adults with high blood pressure should be screened for Type 2 diabetes; findings, which appear in Annals of Internal Medicine, discourage making diabetes testing part of routine medical exam (S)
docs.snippet: Diabetes, a growing public health problem, can cause serious problems, including kidney failure and heart disease, often doing damage before any symptoms are felt. But if it is caught early, a lot of trouble can be prevented.    So should screening...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many parents these days must have more disposable income than my husband and I had when our twin sons were toddlers three decades ago. Certainly today's parents use far more disposable products, especially disposable diapers, for far longer than we did. And diaper companies, ever ready to expand their market, now produce diapers (about 25 cents each) and pull-ups (40 cents each) big enough for 4-year-olds, maybe even 5-year-olds.

headline.main: Plan of Action Can Keep Toddlers Clean and Dry

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses trend toward toilet training children when they are older and gives advice to make toddler's transition more smooth for parent and child; Dr Barton D Schmitt, University of Colorado School of Medicine pediatrics professor, points out that half of children worldwide are toilet trained by one year of age; ways to encourage children to give up diapers described; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many parents these days must have more disposable income than my husband and I had when our twin sons were toddlers three decades ago.    Certainly today's parents use far more disposable products, especially disposable diapers, for far longer than...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Aibo, the robot dog from Sony, has always puzzled me. If you want a robot, why would you want it pretending to be a dog? And if you want a dog, why would you settle for a robot? One look at the roundworm and hookworm pages of the Healthy Pets Healthy People Web site of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (www.cdc.gov /healthypets), provides an answer.

headline.main: What Good Is a Hookworm-Free Robot if It Can't Lick Your Face?

docs.abstract: Animals carry disease, but Centers for Disease Control and Prevention points out that catching anything serious from family pet is unlikely unless family member has compromised immune system; zoonosis, which are illnesses that jump from animals to people, are of increasing concern, but are infrequent; Aibo, Sony's robot dog, is one way to avoid germs and bacteria, but mechanical canine lacks some warmth; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Endometriosis: The Complete Reference for Taking Charge of Your Health,'' by Mary Lou Ballweg and the Endometriosis Association. Contemporary Books, $17.95. ''No More Periods?'' by Dr. Susan Rako. Harmony Books, $21. ''The natural fertility cycle is a great gift of nature,'' writes one expert in the opening of Dr. Rako's book. ''Revel in the cycles of your youth.''
docs.abstract: Dr Susan Rako book No More Periods discusses unknown risks associated with growing trend of menstrual suppression; Endometriosis: The Complete Reference for Taking Charge of Your health by Mary Lou Ballweg and Endometriosis Assn is collaborative effort to inform public about disorder which women of all ages can suffer from; photos (M)
